comments.commentBody: There is political wisdom in Mr. Patten's clear-cut distinction between fighting for democracy and fighting for independence, in case Hong Kong people will gain neither. In his current capacity, Mr. Patten has done his best in Hong Kong's best interest. He is still fondly remembered by the locals and what he says does carry an awful lot of weight.
Pattens rhetoric intervention into HK affairs is the real cause of hurting the HK democratic movement.

I disagreed with the crude language that the two young aspiring legislators used to express their dissent. But you have hit the nail on the head, both when you highlighted the difference between a one-party dictatorship and a constitutional monarchy, and when you reminded us of the Communist Party's reprehensible behaviour.

Thank you.

And why does he think democracy is a good thing to begin with? There is not a single democracy I've lived in, including the United States, that match anywhere the efficiency and nationalism of authoritarian Asian states.

Democracy, for all intents and purposes, is a backwards mode of government that deludes its people into thinking being humane or having equally distributed political power is somehow progress.

Have a look at the protestors in Hong Kong. Nearly all youths with no grasp of history or hierarchy. They are the same kind of social detritus who base their political views on what is or isn't "nice". As it stands, the mature hierarchs of Hong Kong should be glad that the mainland shields it from democracy.
"Efficiency and nationalism" are your measure of a society? Say no more . . .

They are crying out for those who are stiffed and who have no voice.  They are the elected representatives of the people, of their constituents, as simple as that.  Somehow one way or another, HK has to be independent of the nonsense of a failed ideology to go on in justice and peace.  This generation is the most educated of all generations against all odds where people have the right directly or indirectly to pay taxes but no say in many many things.  Let us trust in them and keep them in our prayers.  The future belongs to them and they are paying the price for their generation.

I agree with Mr Patten's views.

From the outside, HK is essentially viewed as a peculiar part of China, which for historical reasons, has been made a testbed for bounded democracy. However, we sense that the Chinese government feels that they are being somewhat generous to HK. Beijing is therefore incensed that rather than feeling grateful, HK is not only seeking more freedom, but even considering independence.

I am not a student of history, but there seems to be very few instances where a state or part of a country can peacefully exit a country without any bloodshed. Even in the USA, if say, California wants to leave the union, it is probably not going to happen as peacefully as the British leaving the EU bloc (which is technically not a country). Taking the relationship between Taiwan and China, you can see how nationalistic things can get when the issue of independence comes up.

As it is difficult to imagine civil war breaking out, or for HK to be truly separate from China, arguing and reasoning for a higher quality of democracy within the confines of Beijing's dictates probably has the greatest chance of success.

I am compelled to point out that Mt. Shasta is, by a considerable margin, the second highest peak in what reasonable minds could consider the Pacific Northwest; at least for purposes of superlative peaks, fixing the southern boundary of the region at the Oregon border seems a bit of a gerrymander.

Sorghum mollases and black strap mollases are entirely different beasts. Sorghum mollases is made from the sorghum plant, a close relative of sugar cane (same genus, _Sorghum), but while sugar cane is grown for the sugar produced from its boiled sap, sorghum is primarily for animal fodder. Both produce mollases, the sap boiled until it thickens. Sorghum mollases has a distinctive flavor, richer than regular mollases from sugar cane.

Blackstrap mollases is the dregs left in the boiler after the sugar has been extracted. It is extremely strong with minerals it contains, and is not suitable for cooking or table use. It is used medicinally for the minerals and formerly as a "spring tonic." No one would make a pie or cookies with it, unless he relished bitterness.
Yes, that was not my intent. My belief was that a reader of my comment read the whole article, and remembered the context of those quotations. My use of them was probably a mistake.
Sometimes a newspaper just has an article of  human interest so you can read something besides just tragic or depressing news.
There is one JR, called Cheaters, usually (not always the cheater is the male) and not all couples are married but the show bursts while the cheater is ¨ in flagrante delicto with his paramour !¨

This is a great article, but there seems to be some confusion not only about the difference between dialects and accents, but also dialects and languages. The linked Reuters article from which the inference that "many" of "nearly 100 Chinese dialects" are spoken by China's 55 recognized ethnic minorities actually states that there are over 100 _languages_ spoken by China's ethnic minorities. Clearly many of these languages, like Tibetan and Uyghur, are not Chinese, while at the same time, many ethnic minorities like the Hui will speak the Chinese dialect or accent of their community or nearby population centers, like Chengdu or Kunming for instance, which would have nothing to do with their ethnicity. Further complicating these distinctions is Cantonese which, when I referred to it once as a "dialect" I was sternly corrected by a venerable historical linguist of Chinese who insisted that Cantonese is a language apart from Putonghua. I didn't pursue the issue, but this might also apply to other "dialects" like Shanghainese. The article is clearly about Beijing dialect, but the 100 number from the UN seems to be of languages spoken in China, not dialects.

By the way, in addition to the project to save Beijinghua, there has since about 2013 been a great international project of preserving all of China's dialects and languages by recording them and posting the recordings to an online interactive map, a kind of digital oral history of China's languages. www.phonemica.net.
Since Beijing dialect is the one I speak at home...

My parents and grandparents are all from Beijing, and by 'from', I mean, born in and residents of for almost their entire lives. They are 'old Beijing', which despite what others may say in the comments, is becoming increasingly harder to find. While that makes me sad, it's the natural by-product of a city that has seen rapid, significant growth in the past decade; to hope otherwise would be naive. I grew up outside China but thanks to my parents I speak Chinese with what I'm often told is a Beijing accent, full of marbles and r's. It's a cultural marker and one that I'm proud of. I might not be able to speak the "tu hua" (transliterally, dirt speech), full of colourful vernacular and vocabulary only a native Beijinger would know, which is what I *think* this author was trying to get at, but whenever I hear an increasing rare phrase or two of it on the street, it's a wonderful throwback.

One thing I don't see in these comments is the racial purity issue found especially in Japan and China.

Mixed races and foreigners will always have a hard time understanding this about the Japanese and Chinese.

I'm not defending these 2 countries' attitudes, just relating that purity of the race is primal and deeply embedded.

Some here, advise to learn the local language, and go native

I think the gentleman here did EXACTLY that, learned the local language, derogations first, and was vituperative and argumentative, over a parking space

oops

but as always "It's Different When WE Do" It fits on a bumper sticker

oops

Fidel and his brother Raúl spent two generations building a cadre of apparatchiks as invested in the current system as they; and those who remain have the military, also invested in the system. You won’t even know that Fidel has gone for at least another generation. The thousands of innocent deaths, the monstrous theft of patrimony as almost one million human beings desperately escaped what had been their country, and the multi-generational economic disaster wrought by this man and his goons remain sacrifices on the altar of a monumental self-regard.

Where would Cubans have been, WHAT would they have been, if not for Fidel? In a better place, having lived better lives.

Anthony:

Possibly, possibly not. Cuba is about three times more populous than Puerto Rico, which would make that kind of dependent vassalage more difficult. Besides, the Cubans never liked Teddy Roosevelt that much -- despite the fact that it was in some part through his (and our) efforts that Cuba gained its independence from Spain.

Otherwise, how you described it ("run by a right-wing dictator", etc.) sounds pretty much like Cuba under Batista.

David:

Your unreasoning hatred never fails to make an appearance, does it? Just because Batista was an exploitative dictator doesn't justify in his stead yet another exploitative dictator.

Those deaths were not innocent deaths...they were the 'goons' of Batista and his brutal dictatorship, supported by the US. My husband was there, he lived through it. Theft of patrimony? Yes, he did.
Economic disaster? Try 60 years of embargo by the richest nation in the world. Try economic isolation promulgated by the US.
And, we not only prevented American companies from doing business, we punished, and continue to try to punish, any foreign company that does business with the US and also Cuba.
The wet-foot-dry foot policy was put into place specifically to entice poor Cubans to leave their island....they get to Florida and have all sorts of benefits waiting for them. Do we do it because we are nice?? No.

Again, if Fidel did one thing right, he helped reinforce nationalism in his country. And, reminded his people that they are an independent nation.
Reminded them of the legacy of Jose Marti.
Long live a free Cuba, free from the meddling of the US and any other superpower.
. . . or David Oistrakh.

Disbelieving and still suffering from PTSD-type symptoms hearing Trump had become the "president-elect". Then I started to do some research and discovered that 29 million Americans vote on antiquated and insecure voting machines. Two nationally-renown and credible computer experts write:  “We know that the national results could be tipped by manipulating the vote count in a relatively small number of jurisdictions — a few dozen spread across a few key states. We know that the vast majority of local elections officials have limited resources to detect or defend against cyber attacks. And while pre-election polls have large uncertainties, they were consistently off. And various aspects of the preliminary results, such as a high rate of undervotes for president, have aroused suspicion. Source: “Still Time for an Election Audit” – 11/18/2016 – USA Today, by Professors Ron Rivest & Philip Stark

Thank you so much for the consideration of grace notes. I had always thought of them as little embellishments that grace the piece, but will never be able to think of them that simplistically again.

During my cancer journey I communicated with my far-flung friends and family only when I was doing relatively well, when I could make light of the situation and discuss it with a certain amount of breeziness. There was no point in making these folks feel worse for me than they already did, as they were not in a position to do much else except send good wishes. Which is a lot.

But now I have the false and undeserved reputation as the brave cancer sufferer/survivor. And it is hard to summon the apparent grace to accept this praise. Really, I only did it to spare them worry about me.

"Really, I only did it to spare them worry about me."

To me, that is the embodiment of grace under pressure.
Me too, Barry. It's nine in the morning (Monday morning) here and still no column or comments. I just rushed here to say Happy Birthday to suejean!
Most assuredly., polymath.

Marxism and Fascism are two sides of the same coin. One is far left, the other far right.

We have just put the other side of the coin in the presidents office. Can our political system keep them from excess. Will critics of DJT find themselves being watched, will our justice system keep us safe from GOP goons?

Will books that criticize and expose the administration be banned,? will the windows of shops owned by Mexicans and Muslims be broken one night?
Will the military follow orders that are in violation of the constitution?

Castro gained power as a revolt against a U.S. buddy, Fulgencio Batista who was a favorite of GOP senators and congressmen. Who gave special access to certain American companies, who want the property he gave them back. He allowed the Mafia to build and operate hotels and casinos that hosted such fine Americans as j.Edgar Hoover while looting the country.

Castro was simply the final result of such rule, the same as Stalin came to power as a revolt against the rule of the Czars. Autocrats are no different no matter what they call their rule. We now have the advent of our own would be autocrat, and his followers resemble those of Castro's, Franco's, Lenin's, Peron's, and Adolf's, just different names.

We are in for turbulent times. The inmates have taken over the funny farm.

Oh how Luettgen likes to rewrite history.

He writes as though Cuba was democratic paradise run by those who had nothing but the welfare of the Cubans at heart. If Castro had not taken over, the friends and relatives of the benevolent Fugliencio Batista would have continued of what RL considers a better place. One of casinos, hotels full of Cosa Nostra visitors, prostitutes and of course profitable American companies,who could acquire ordinary Cubans property for pennies.

Oh sure many Cubans did prosper from this arrangement, all it takes is a little mordida. You think those American companies running nickle mines and telephone systems just applied for a license,and were welcomed as good examples of democracy?

You would do well writing history books for the Texas school system,

We've known, since 2014, thanks to a Princeton University study, that America is an oligarchy. If the idea was theoretical when the study was published, it now no longer is theory but fact, no longer hidden, but in all of our faces. Trump ran on draining the swamp. Keith Ellison is right. Trump isn't draining it but filling it.

Trump told his voters he would change the way the GOP operates, with insiders reaping the benefits and change the way Washington works for the voters. The only thing Trump seems to be changing is cutting out the GOP middleman. Gone will be those who pretend to be part of a political party. The oligarchs will be running things out in the open, instead.

News reports indicate that Governors, GOP and Democrats, are getting ready to fight Paul Ryan on privatizing Medicare and dismantling Obamacare.

Let the likes of Ryan and McConnell be seen in the open doing the bidding of Trump and his fellow oligarchs and plutocrats. Let the public take it all in. Let the Democrats clean house and form the greatest opposition ever. Ellison, Sanders, Warren, Gabbard, Schumer and all the Democrats' job will be to call out Trump and his cronies for every last corrupt deal they'll make. Meanwhile, Democrats need to clean house and rebuild the party to ensure 2018 is the year they regain control of Congress.

--

Silent Class Revolt: http://www.rimaregas.com/2016/11/silent-class-revolt-most-democrats-vote...

Rachel,

The Senate part of the equation has been settled, as I point out in my piece. The House leadership vote takes place on Wednesday. Few have spoken publicly about where they stand, but it is apparent that the establishment leadership is not ready to cede power. Keith Ellison is facing a tremendous amount of opposition and March is a long way away.

If progressives don't find the courage to up and go, Democrats will lose elections until they reach oblivion. As it stands, they've lost much of the share of the vote they had in the South and elsewhere.
Well done, Rima. You have taken a lot of flak, but this time you are absolutely spot on. Thank you.

Because if a bunch of lefty liberal grad students or professors, at a lefty liberal college, in the lefty liberal Northeast...publish a lefty liberal "study" on something, then that is SCIENTIFIC FACT and cannot be disputed.
